i was re-playing Fallout4 while listening to this, and its just another example added to the litany of not just poorly, but seemingly maliciously poorly made games. ive come to the conclusion that game developers have used analysts to determine the point where a game IP development cost to investment ration is most profitable & what is happening is developers start making a game, it could be good even, but they approach the 'its no longer profitable' point and are forced to just end the project as is, leaving a broken husk of a IP. its why you will often see a glimmer of something in the bad game, like it started with good ideas, but the person who had them was removed from the project. they release the junk & you might think 'junk isnt profitable', and you'd be right with most things, but not games. as long as gamers buy it, and dont refund it, it can be profitable, especially if they keep investments low. leading to where we are now, a low effort low outcome game industry.

Small side note (and really not important): Deus Ex is frequently cited as the immersive sim grandfather of hurdles that you *at least* have to clear, but while it is the most well-known next to System Shock 2, the grandfathering more belongs to System Shock 1 or, if we're being honest, Ultima Underworld back in 1992 which showed the design elements that like you quote defined the approach to immersive sims.

My perfect example of how an immersive sim works: You have to cross a river, over the river spans a bridge, but there are three orcs that want a toll.  - You can fight them  - You can simply pay them   - You can use your strong physique to intimidate them  - You can use your charisma to convince them to let you pass  - You can use your bartering skills to lower the toll  - You can use your crafting and engineering skills to build a raft to cross the river  - You can use your magic to put them to sleep  - You can wait for night and sneak past them  - You can use the fact that you helped their chief last week and they let you pass because you are a friend of their tribe  - You can use alcohol to get them drunk  - You can use bardic music to charm them  - You can use your superhuman endurance and just swim over  - You can jump over the river  - You can use frost magic to freeze the river and walk over the ice  - You can show them a writ from the king that you are on a super important quest, and they let you pass, because the goal of that quest is in their best interest  The challenge is not "defeat the orcs to cross the river" The challenge is "find a way to cross the river"

Seeing this always reminds me of the days the devs had to put out quality games to even get sales. And with that I mean you only got those games from store shelfs where there is no quick little patches to fix things, either stuff got bug fixed before it hit the shelfs or it stayed in. But that's how we had gems of games. Now the standard is so fucking low because everything is "Early-access" and $60-$70 games feel like they should still be in beta but are released. "If it doesn't work we patch it for 5 years to be eventually playable when nobody plays this game anymore" - probably some of them.  It's just insane to me. I'd rather spend $60 on a couple amazing indie games worth their money than spend the same amount on one game that shouldn't have gotten released and would've needed another year or two in development to be where even the devs hope it would be. That's also why I don't by AAA games anymore. A bunch of studios can't be trusted anymore, because this shit is getting so out of hand and they still, SOMEHOW, are getting away with those ambitious games with way to short of a development cicle... and people still buy those games and wonder why it sucked.  I don't want to knock on the dev team, some more than others, do what they can. It's more the higher ups that decide when they release the game and clearly most of them underestimate the costs and development cicle and rather pump out a garbage game to get some money, rather than deliver a good and promised game, which you can then hook new players and get new fans following what the team does next.  I'm sure it's fairly obvious where I stand on games like this. I hate this type of development in games and it's been going like this for a while now, atleast eversince the digital copies/Steam store took off. If those studios can't finish to make a thoughtout, exciting and properly developed game from the get go without it needing 15 hundred patches to fix everything, then why bother spending your hard earned money for those $60-$70 glorified doorstoppers?  But more and more games every year come out with this god forsaken "beta version game releases as full game" trend and this fucking shit needs to stop.

I agree with most of your points, but there‚Äôs a couple of things I‚Äôd like to push back on.    If we‚Äôre being fair, it‚Äôs not the devs that aren‚Äôt putting in the work.  It‚Äôs 100% the execs that are forcing the game out before it‚Äôs ready.  They have the timeline, they don‚Äôt care, they just want the money.   Regarding notes and gunplay, I‚Äôve seen this same mentality from a few other review channels, but it is a little frustrating to see a player that primarily enjoys the shooter aspect to then criticise storytelling or other aspects of the game that are a bit slower because they don‚Äôt have the patience to sit still and listen.  Or to read a logbook.  Yes, this game in general was badly done, but marking it down for aspects that you, personally, find boring is a little disingenuous.    I can understand how the switching weapons and limited options when it comes to weaponry would be frustrating for a player who enjoys that sort of thing or is very good at it.  I‚Äôm not very good at it, so personally, the limited options really appeals to me.  It gives me a limited arsenal to learn and become proficient in without being overwhelming.  Provided controls are improved at a latter date, of course.  Overall, I really do agree with your assessment of the game.  This is a disappointing show from Arcane, but I wanted to point out that the devs are not to blame and a game can be enjoyed in multiple ways, not just from the perspective of a shooter.

i have a feeling what we are seeing here is industrial espionage, with the field of video game development being what it is the competition is fierce and the margin of error is really low. if a video game publisher were to release a really good AAA game and a competing publisher were to release an equally good AAA game it would mean that there were now two really good AAA games competing on the field which is not good for the publisher. one thing this publisher could do (provided that they have the resources for it) is to covertly send some of their men to the competing publisher and have them act on grassroots level to corrupt the general atmosphere of the company and pressure the skilled developers to leave. if these skilled developers were to leave this publisher could siphon this skill for themselves while the competition is left with developers who don't know what they are doing. now what happens in the next cycle is that you worked hard to create a good video game while they fumbled to put together a game that is absolute dogshit so now you will have people praising your work while forgetting about the competition's product.  but i do still see a glimmer of hope, UE5 and ChatGPT-4 have made video game development much more accessible and i could see that within the next decade small dev teams (maybe even one-man dev teams) could be able to handle AAA quality development. this would mean a lot more healthy competition in the field and much more importantly creative skill which seems to be desperately needed in the AAA development these days.

There is Aim Assist.  It is Keyboard/mouse exclusive.  WTF?  Yes!
So "input response preset" probably describes the curve used to map different ranges of thumbstick angles to in-game rotation values.   Most people *think* that their thumbstick movements are mapped to a linear function, i.e "push the stick halfway forward to move at half speed", but the overwhelming majority of times, that transition is smoothed on a curve -- many console FPS games nowadays allow you to adjust that curve to your liking.  I haven't played Redfall and almost certainly never will, but I wonder if the controls aren't *quite* that abysmal, and that the problem is more that they don't do a good job (or really even make an attempt to) explain this concept to the player.  Tldr changing that setting in games tends to have a huge impact on game feel, so there *might* be a universe in which the controls are merely "bad" and not "utter garbage".

This is up there with a few articles from restaurant critics as one of the most hilarious critiques of anything I‚Äôve ever seen.  The breaks to show gameplay are inspired.
The games industry got dogpiled by legions of soulless spreadsheet wizards with all the loyalty to fanbases, respect for IP's and utter, balls-out depravity in the way they both treat the people they expect to buy their products but crucially, their own workforce : a cohesive team of artists and creators trying to create an experience that the brain-trust upstairs couldn't sh@t onto a disc if their 401k's depended on it.   And the carousel spins - the franchises change, but the hype and lofty promises are all the same flavour of bullshit they've already coated the walls with from the last ad-campaign.   It's all feeling Kickstartery to me - some of the whoppers being sold in recent years in ad campaigns that dwarfed production budgets to the extent that all it came to symbolize come Launch Day as the GDP of several nations in the shape of a giant middle finger aimed at it's customers (yes, they all signed it üòí EA still managed to take up most of the real estate, again) set ablaze to a club remix of Money Money Money vs Know Your Enemy..........I'd sooner throw money at the Kickstarter with the funny ideas about what counts as a prostitution ring üòê  We see corruption worn-in and shady in other industries, we hear the horror stories of the lives caught between the gears of an old and immovable agenda, with the influence of the average malevolent corporation - we receive less and less reason to put faith in anything being shoved down ear canals and up against our tired eyeballs.  The very  I a s t  thing that people deserve to have ruined for them in this day and age, are the very finite, often singular purchases that contain the potential (ahem) to take us far, far away from alllllll the other products we're overcharged for that are inherently deceptive, hide flaws that range from poor quality all the way up to being harmful to those who've recently parted with cash earned in a seemingly caustic society, pre-wired to see/hear offense and one that, rain/shine, is always announcing rate hikes, reductions, losses and redundancies.  You could at least proudly sell me a presentable, quality way off this planet in the meantime.

I personally do not think this video is a fair representation of Redfall.  I have played through Redfall completely on all characters on PC.  I agree there are optimization issues that shouldn't be there on a game just released but shit happens.  While this video just sits here and points out all the things they think are bad about this game, they neglect to point out the things that are actually a lot of fun.  The shooting / gun play (with keyboard and mouse) is a lot of fun and can create a lot of interesting combinations, The story itself is really good if you actually pay attention to what is going on.  And speaking of the story, if you do not 100% complete the grave locks in this game, you will not know the entire story.   I agree it was released with bugs and optimization problems that it shouldn't have been released with, but the game as a whole is actually a very fun and interesting game to play.

Check the game's credits. Whilst there's still veterans in key positions even at the Austin studio, 70-80% of the world/level design team consists of people who've never worked on an Arkane game before -- but rather open world stuff all over the industry, from Mafia to Saints Row over Far Cry and Destiny. The OW design lead previousl worked at Bioware on ME Andromeda and ... (fittingly?) Anthem. A lot of these people where hired as recent as early 2022 too according to their LinkedIn (which probably says a bit about the game's development process...)  That's not accounting for the people that Colantonio took with his to WolfEye after Prey -- the "flop" that hurt some. The credits of Weird West show more than a dozen people who've prior worked at Arkane or collaborated with them. Prey's system lead meanwhile has moved on to Bungie. Rich Wilson, lead level designer on Prey, is at Archetype.

Since you didn't really play multiplayer, I would like to present to you the multiplayer experience.  1) You can't see your teammate's shots. When they shoot, nothing happens. It looks like they are force users and enemies just die for no reason from their force choke move. I thought I'd made an error and set the game to low detail, but nope. Arkane seem to have decided teammate bullet animations are going to be too system heavy.   2) Teammates often animation glitch, and for a good part of one session, my friend's character decided he'd prefer to live in the floor for my view, strobe glitching in and out of it. After we fast traveled to try fix this, his character turned into a vampire and decided to float everywhere instead. I tried to exit to fix it, and that's where I discovered point 3."  3) If you quit a multiplayer session, it quits EVERYONE and progress to that point is sometimes totally lost. Their matchmaking system is from the early 2000s. You have to invite a player before you enter the game, and enter together. You can't just jump in and out of your friend's session, you either start together, or you have to get them to start it with you. There was a bug at some point which force disconnected me, and everyone else was quit out. We lost 2 hours of progress too since upon realoading, it hadn't saved for some reason.  It was at that point, everyone involved uninstalled the game since we were all playing it on the PC gamepass, and were done with it's bullshit. The business of AAA video gaming is broken and is hurting the players while making the dev studios tons of money. Games promised and never delivered, games released in a condition that requires multiple post-release patches before they are ready to play, or games that just never live up to the months or years of marketing hype that preceded the release.  A ton of the blame falls on the large studios making these games, but we the players share in that blame. We have continued to buy sub-par products, pay for DLCs and updates to a game that we are only marginally happy with. We even pre-order games months in advance, essentially loaning money to the likes of EA and Ubisoft. It is clear that game developers are not going to change their practices, so it is up to the players to force change upon them. Players can bring about change if we do the following 7 things:  1. Stop pre-ordering games. Paying money for something that does not even exist is called investing or speculation, not buying. Pre-ordering perversely incentivizes game producers to create and ship products before they are ready for RTM (release to market). We don‚Äôt pay for clothes, cars, or pretty much anything before they exist. Why do we do this with video games?  2. Stop buying games based solely on a trailer. A trailer tells you NOTHING about the game and should never be the basis for a buying decision. It is just a movie and may have nothing in common with the game experience. For God‚Äôs sake, the trailer for The Day Before, a game that seems unlikely to ever come into being, caused that game to be the #1 wishlisted game on Steam. If a pre-order of TDB had been available, it could easily have been the biggest video game money pit of all time.  3. Insist that all AAA games have a limited free-to-play option. The F2P option can be a final Beta just prior to release, contain limited levels, be available for a limited time, or even have reduced functionality, but players need to get their hands on a game BEFORE they shell out good money. It is too bad it has come to this, but there have been too many major game releases that were not worth the money we paid for them until months after release‚Ä¶and we had no way of knowing that until we paid. I guess an alternative to the F2P option would either be a ‚Äúdelayed payment‚Äù option where the company does not charge our credit card for a number of days after the purchase, thus allowing us to cancel, or by offering an easy-to-claim money-back guarantee.  4. Stop supporting fan-boy content creators who add to the hype of a game before they know anything more than what the trailer showed them. Support content creators who give honest, clearly articulated reviews of a game and accurately report gaming news when it occurs. You know the routine, LIKE, SUBSCRIBE, and click the notification bell.  5. Describe your experience, good or bad, on social media with rational, calm, evaluations and reports of player experiences. That is what developers pay attention to. Not, wild screaming and yelling about how awful the game is without any concrete examples of the issues being encountered. And don‚Äôt forget to praise a game or developer that does a good job. Always throwing out complaints is another good way to be ignored.  6. Don‚Äôt play games that you don‚Äôt like. Some of the loudest complainers are those players who continue to rack up hundreds or thousands of hours in a game. If you really think a game is so bad that you can spend hours complaining, then don‚Äôt spend hours playing. Game developers watch player levels, and if the hours of gameplay and the number of concurrent players remain high, they will ignore any and all complaints.   7. Do not cover games that embargo reviews prior to release. Any developer that is afraid of reviews probably has a reason for that. Placing an embargo on reviews is s sure sign of fear.   Players can bring change to this market, but it may not be easy. Be informed buyers and do not let all the hype from a good marketing campaign cause you to pay good money for bad games.

Its really unfortunate how this game turned out. The overall concept was a really good one. A vampire hero shooter. It hasn't been done before and vampires are a really unexplored setting for games. Unfortunately we got this. This can't be patched. I don't even think Arkane announcing they are going to take the servers offline and redo everything would fix this. This unfortunately will just be a failed concept. That really hurts to see new ideas butchered. I have a feeling other devs will see this and get the idea that the concept is what killed this game. It's not. What killed this game was something that has been plaguing this industry for a while. games being released in a state (like this), and just expecting audiences to practically invest in an unfinished project. Then players hoping it will get finished in a few years after release. Video games aren't a get rich quick scheme and they aren't a investment. They are a beautiful form of entertainment meant to share ideas, emotions, and stories in a way never seen before. The fact that the industry has become nothing but a money generator is nothing short of a tragedy.

I have to say, my dude, your creativity in how you review video games is absolutely top notch. When you have interest and really enjoy something, it directly is reflected in the style of how your review or take goes. Kudos to Austin, as well, for understanding your ideas and concepts, and flowing things together with a mutual cohesion. And that being said, the transition cuts with generic font to intersplice your video from segment to segment is the perfect reflection of both your thoughts and the general experience with this game. I never have seen a review that both does such a great job at really nailing down the problems, and at the same time, demonstrates the seemingly bland generic attitude of the game that is actually being reviewed by mimicking it in presentation. About the only harsh thing I will say is:  'You don't go from Prey Mooncrash to this. That is not explainable by just the pandemic or whatever'  Oh yes you do, my friend. Yes you do and yes it is. You lose a whole bunch of staff to the pandemic and all its multitude of knock-on effects (long covid, dealing with the fallout of deaths, dealing with friends and family WITH long covid, dealing with family who are dealing with the fallout of loss, et cetera et cetera) as well as years of development disruption from all this, and this can absolutely be the result.  When people say that we are going to be feeling the effects of the pandemic (which is not properly over, even, let's be clear) they are not fucking around. Issues like this are going to crop up for years to come.  Anyway, this is otherwise an excellent review and up to your usual standards. I'm glad you weren't afraid to take the game to task over being less sophisticated, in many ways, than Half-Life or OG Deus Ex, which are games that are or are nearly a quarter-century old. Even if the game was clobbered by covid, it was on Microsoft to say "no, this simply is not worth releasing, we are going to scrap it". They didn't, and this is what they're trying to foist as an exclusive as a result.  Just... absolutely do not underestimate the damage the pandemic has done (and is still doing!) to game development.

Arkane is one of my favorite developers and the Dishonored series is on the list among my all-time favorite video games/franchises, but from the moment Redfall was announced and marketed it looked so uninteresting and out of character for them. As the marketing rolled out nothing about that changed, and as it got closer to release it just seemed uninspired, half-baked, and the game itself looked very far from finished and ready to be released.    I worried that they were trying to (or were instructed to) make a gimmicky multiplayer looter shooter rather than the narrative-driven immersive sim experiences they have excelled at creating, and ppl would say "no its gonna be a single player experience just w co-op" but the released game bears all the hallmarks of a developer half-heartedly trying to put together a gimmicky multiplayer looter shooter and inevitably having the unfinished product shoved out the door in an embarrassing state to meet publisher-mandated financial deadlines.   It's sad to see from Arkane, and it's kind of just another indictment of the current stagnant and lazy profit chase of the AAA game industry. There's hardly ever middling or decent AAA games anymore to pass your time with, there's either fully baked tentpole franchise releases or embarrassing, buggy unfinished disasters that probably never should have been greenlit, go in completely the wrong direction chasing after ill-fitting trends that people dont really like to begin with, and arent given nearly enough development time to be turned into anything interesting or worthwhile.   The industry is not handling longer, more labor intensive modern game development with any dignity or better management. They're developing games on the same schedules, charging more for them, and releasing undercooked, flat out unfinished games that are widely panned if not brutally mocked. When the games turn into financial failures its always the overworked developers who are made to suffer for the ill-suited trend-chasing and poor management, while the arrogant scumbag Bobby Koticks of the world expect their fat greedy purses to always be overflowing.

Microsoft's answer for their IP is Starfield. Its highly likely all resources were put on that project while oversight, resourcing and quality staffing of this game was largely redirected. They want their best on something with the most potential, and they saw Redfall as something that never picked up steam so they put newer developers they're training on Redfall as a learning point with much less threat. Redfall was most likely planned and committed to a long time ago, never picked up steam, then died out as the release date was pushed to far right to a major IP release. The smart thing to do in that situation as an organization would be to devote your resources to the much higher risk with a release looming in the near future.

Do you remember when The Elder Scholls VI was announced? Bear with me.   Every time a huge title is announced these days, you get the uber excited gamer detectives who investigate everything to do with said title and the developers behind it. Well, these detectives discovered that around the time TES6 was revealed to be in development and the dragonborn massive went mental for this announcement, that Bethesda had registered the name 'Redfall'. Of course, we all put duck and wrench together and got pineapple, assuming it was going to be the name of the next Elder Scrolls game.  I mean it sounded plausible and it sounded cool and yeah, we all felt pretty smart that we'd spoiled their reveal a little. Not long after this, Bethesda came out with another reveal for a quirky, stylised, vampire shooter called Redfall. Why? Because we still live in the early 2000's and this is fresh and interesting.......no! This game never looked interesting and.....well I was sceptical. And here is where I went a bit conspiracy theory.   I kinda thought that maybe, just maybe, Bethesda had the downright despicablably, immensely big balls to not only announce a new ip game to hide the fact they had a huuuuuuge reveal opportunity in the future spoilt but once we started seeing artwork for this Redfall game, actually make that game. Surely not right.   And with arkane doing this, it's going to maybe be half decent, even if the subject and style feels old hat! Right? Well, now I've seen what they have churned out with Redfall. Oh god no. Nooooooooooo! You know the meme. Surely this IS a meme game that they have released here. It's almost as if Bethesda said 'Fuuuuck! We need a game doing, please. Here's your release window, let's just get out some trash and everyone will forget about TES while we think of something else. Oh and starfield isn't going to be ready for ages so we might as well because....money?'   Jesus, what in the hamster hell made them think this was a good idea from conception to release. I'm sure I am wrong about the meme game thing after having the Redfall name being leaked, but damn, the more I see of this game the more I'm believing my dumb bullshit. I hope you're happy Bethesda. Oh c'mon, the empty map is not a bug, or bad game design, it is actually a well-thought-out feature. See, Arkane had a little trouble figuring how to stop gameplay while in the menus, so they came up with the ingenious solution that is: "The Empty Map." This modern solution reduces the potential of being attacked in one's menu to near-zero by removing the majority of threats on the map. Now, you'll never have to fear that a sneaky vampire might take advantage of you while you're not looking, because there are no vampires. Badabing badaboom, it is gamer approved.

Y'all need to stop buying AAA games at release....
Did things change because of some launch patch or something? We haven't run into a lot of these problems.  My friends and I have been playing on Xbox and we're not having these control issues at all (other than being a bit annoyed at having to cycle through the weapons). I did notice that the aim acceleration is really crazy outside of ADS, but after adjusting to it it's fine. It seems like the intention is for you to be able to track the teleporting vampires outside of ADS, then ADS right when you go to fire and hit them right in the head, then back out of ADS again after you get your damage burst out. This is especially apparent with the UV guns (that focus the beam when you ADS, and widen the beam when you don't). Also, if anything, the aim assist seems stronger than most games and it feels like it locks right to the enemies a lot of the time. Maybe it doesn't have this level of aim assist if you play with a controller but on the PC?  We also haven't had the issue with low enemy count. Is that due to scaling for multiplayer, maybe, or just a change they made at launch? For example, the theater you used as an example had a lot of human enemies for us, along with a vampire that blocked our vision and had revolving energy shields (like those Vex bosses in Destiny).  It's interesting for me seeing these reviews from people who were overall positive about Dead Island 2, but are really trashing Redfall. My friends and I have played Arkane's past games, so we even still have that comparison to bring our opinions down, but we still immediately enjoyed this game more than Dead Island 2. Granted we've only played for a couple of nights so it might get boring faster,  but so far we've just found Redfall to be more fun and interesting to play, and we've found the main characters to be a lot more interesting. Not to mention a lot of little touches that are genuinely cool, like building trust levels with co-op partners and the characters having conversations with each other based on that, or the different weapon rarity levels making the same gun look really noticeably different, or most quests not giving exact direction and having to explore areas to figure out what you're supposed to do.  It just feels like there are at least some double standards going on when it comes to people's reactions to Dead Island 2 and Redfall, but maybe we just haven't played enough of them yet.

Things like these are a proof of broken management system of capitalism, where money decisions and the fact of a "timely release" is above the product, above the user experience and developer ownership of this product. Developers do not own the software anymore, it is owned by finance oriented management that has no idea how to make things. "We need to release something, so release whatever you have" is, unfortunately too often of a situation with software nowadays in general. This is another reason indie games nowadays have higher quality than any AAA release. Indie dev company can only survive if people play their game and like their game. And they can only do that if that game is good and their friend told them about it, not because they have millions of dollars in marketing brainwashing people to believe this is going to be a hit.  None of this is a fault of Arkane imo. I am sure they feel absolutely horrible releasing this game and listening to all this aggressive feedback. They were obviously forced to do this.

I'm probably stating the obvious, but we need to acknowledge that the gaming industry officially has no brand quality assurance. We once trusted rock star developers and rock star studios, both of which have failed on banking on their names. Game development is a black hole of talent, which rapidly destroys anything that falls in. The men and women you think are geniuses exist only in the past, and what exists today, talking and boasting to you on YouTube PR videos, are just Theseus's Ships of degrading cell matter.   The same can be said of game studios, whose people cycle out so rapidly that none of the knowledge or talent is retained in the group.  At this point I could possibly cite Nintendo, From Software, or Capcom as businesses that have adhered to some standard, but this is just the nostalgia and cherry picking of a fallible mind. The laws of entropy apply to everything, and whatever talent these studios have will age and die off like anything else, leaving the corporatized brain dead drones to man the computers in their wake.  The point of all this is that you need to stop looking at who's developing what, and just see the individual products that come out. Brand quality in the gaming industry is just another trick of the hype machine. It no longer exists, save only to lie to you to take your money.
Microsoft are a joke company when it comes to gaming. All that money and they can‚Äôt put out a good game. Anyone cheering for them to swallow up all the big studios/publishers need to realise they‚Äôre pretty useless and it will harm the medium we love.

This game is worse than those Adobe Flash browser games back in the day.
This is what happens when media give deathloop, an indie game packaged as AAA, a free pass.  The company didn't "suddenly go bad" in a day, there were warning signs all these years.
Bethesda (the developer) and Arkane have something in common: they are relatively low tech developers that focus on world building over sophisticated graphics, multiplayer, etc.  Bioware is another, non-Microsoft company who are also like this.  Their strengths are everywhere except technical.  So for these developers to decide (or be ordered) to make a multiplayer looter shooter is a massive strategic blunder.  Developers, like any profession, have strengths and expertise in certain areas.  Many corporate business types don't understand this.  They think that if a developer can do a game, then they can do any game.  If the devs complain, they just get given more time, but not enough extra time.  An extreme amount of extra time is needed for a dev team to make a game they lack experience in.  We saw it with Anthem and Fallout 76.  Plus, if the devs lack confidence or interest, they will be even slower. If Arkane/Microsoft had any sense, what they should do is abandon Redfall and use the assets and maybe even the theme (vampires) to make a single player game that plays to Arkane's strengths, rather than trying to patch up a game like Redfall where they clearly lack experience and interest.  Maybe even give a discount to people who bought Redfall outright (not that I think that likely).
The graphics look worse than anything I've played in 2007

The only thing is that you *can't* just 'take the L and go', because if you do just say "Holy shit, we fucked up this video game really badly and it's not worth fixing", then the whole live service grift falls apart. Releasing broken, unfinished, and frankly unsalvagable games is what Live Service is all about, and if you break kayfabe by saying that the games *won't* ever be good because that requires the fully unhinged support of a Sunk-Cost locked audience that it flatly won't get, then the whole grift has the bottom fall out and when it's time for the NEXT one, you might get less buy in for your $70 dollar Anthem.

1:51 memus
The AAA industry has been in a messy state for over a decade now. The Titans that use to be trend setters (Bethesda, Activision, Ubisoft, etc.) became the trend chasers starting as early as 2011, and it's resulted in the overall quality of games decreasing tenfold since then. There is no excuse for an entire industry to be failing at performing the bare minimum to ship a functioning product, and yet we continue to see poorly optimized games with insidious marketplaces dominating the release calendar time and time again.  It speaks volumes that the primary force propping up the entire gaming industry is the indi sector as we continue to see small time development studios innovate and adapt. Valheim, RimWorld, Factorio, and countless other games have absolutely embarrassed the AAA industry by producing higher quality games, selling the for <$40, and generating enough profits to continue innovating.    I still can't believe there are people out there trying to justify the $70 price tag either. I guess some people are masochists and love the pain?
I'd argue that Fallout 76, while an unquestionably broken mess at launch, has improved somewhat over time with updates and content additions, and I know many dedicated players who find genuine, unironic enjoyment playing it (I was one of them until I got burned out and wanted to move on).  I don't see that happening with Redfall.  The work that would have to go into fixing this game would be so extensive that they'd pretty much have to tear it down and rebuild from the ground up, and we all know that's not going to happen.
Dear Microsoft, please hire Skill Up. Amen.

19:12 I think what's happening here is that there is a tutorial/mission complete window displaying, which requires you to hold B to close. For some reason, this menu is prioritized above *all other menus* in the game, EVEN THE PAUSE MENU, despite not being visually LAYERED that way. This happened to me several times and I bet it's what's happening to you.  It makes it arguably worse than if this were a glitch, since this mockery of UX is *by design.*  There were also times I would open up a note to read it and I would get that window, blurred to my right side, forcing me to close it before closing the note in the foreground of my screen. It's unintuitive and absurd in design to the point that I can't think of a single other video game that has *literally ever* made the same mistake.

Cutscenes that are not animated may not necessarily be bad, as they represent a distinct art form where still images are used to convey a story. It is possible that non-animated cutscenes were chosen due to budget constraints or as a deliberate stylistic choice. While cost may have been a factor, the end result can still be engaging and enjoyable to watch.

As I've said  many times before, i think this game is a product of executive/corporate influence.  In a manner similar to 76 I believe that executives pushed Arkane to make a multiplayer experience to appeal to wider audiences and sell more copies, because while Arkane's other games like Dishonoured and Prey are absolute masterpieces of stealth and immersive-sim gameplay, they have a somewhat niche audience and appeal, compared to a cooperative shooter experience.  This is yet another example of what happens when you give a primarily single player game studio , a multiplayer game to make -- I don't think dev time was an issue here (because Redfall was seemingly in development for 5 years), rather I think the studio didnt have the expertise or interest to make a multiplayer looter shooter.  This genre of game is such an odd departure from their usual games, that it's hard to beleive that they genuinely wanted to make something like this -- especially since Redfall looks mechanically neutered in terms of it's powers compared to Dishonoured and Prey.  Even Deathloop , which i think was Arkane's first miss, is much more mechanically sound and fun compared to Redfall.  Be it Machine games and wolfenstein youngblood, Bethesda ganne stuios and Fallout 76, Bioware and Anthem, and now Arkane and Redfall -- pushing Single player studios to develop multiplayer-centric experiences just does not work. Give these talented studios the freedom they deserve to make the games they want.

I wasn't a big fan of deathloop but i can see it being a fun game to others just like how i could see some people not liking pray but almost all their games allow us to approach combat in different ways and its shocking that redfall lacks that.   Arkane released Arx Fatalis and dark messiah, two games i could argue were designed around player choice and freedom to approach however you want, i remember playing dark messiah and thinking it would be a typical rpg game but man was i wrong, i went into fights like i was a mage or warrior and got my ass handed to me. It  wasn't until i started playing like a underhanded cheat that the combat really clicked and the creative ways to approach combat is something i don't think we seen since and it was one of my favourite parts of the game aside from the succubus.   Im disappointed that arkane even released a game like this where i didn't really feel like i could approch the combat in any unique or different way. All i could really do was sneak or go in guns blazing, there was no real alternate paths to take and there is no point in sneaking since the ai is braindead half the time. I hope arkane gets on the right track and releases a good game soon, they are one of my favourite developers and have put out some fantastic games and would hate to see them go downhill like some other devs.

We must take a stand and demand change.  The time has come for us to rise up and say "enough is enough." We cannot continue to let game developers and publishers take advantage of us with overpriced DLC, microtransactions, and loot boxes. Since Deathloop, and arguably also around when Raphael Colantonio left, something has definitely felt very wrong at Arkane. And I do think we should hold off on throwing them off a cliff until we know what is going on at that company.   Now I'm not trying to say that we should give them a free pass because "it's Arkane", not all. Especially because that's how we ended up with modern Bethesda and we didn't stand for it when BioWare showed its cracks. But I'm really tempted to say we should wait for a thorough journalistic investigation as to what the hell happened during the development of Deathloop and Redfall. Because this is now a bad game from each of Arkane's two studios and they are clearly not working with the same resources when they built Dishonored 2 and Prey. It REALLY doesn't matter if you didn't like those games or you preferred Dishonored 1 or whatever your opinion about those games was. I don't think it's absurd to say that on a technical level, those two games were dripping in polish and innovation, and they both played extremely well with many deeply engaging mechanical systems. These aspects are very clearly absent from Deathloop and Redfall and this is what makes me wonder WTF is going on at Arkane.  Absolutely, we should critique these games as failed products that are VERY sub-par and completely unacceptable as AAA releases. But I would say let's cool off on hating on the devs until we get a bigger picture, ironically, "because it's Arkane."

My biggest issues isnt the cutback on cutschenes or lack of a good story, or failure to provide a singleplayer experience, it is a co-op shooter afterall. HOWEVER what is unforgiving, is the VERY bad grafix , with VERY bad pc preformance, AND an entirely EMPTY world for a looter-shooter, on top of mainly borring powers and uninspired upgrades and a horrible way to go around loot, @autosalvage loot for money, and no CRAFTING or funny interactions with it what so ever. THEN on top of these issues it has the absolute worst and easyest AI i have ever played against, at this point they would have made a better game if they made it 4vs 4 pvp, at least i may have had some interresting gunfigths then. Also a LOT of stupid decisions was made for co-op and lack of mission progress. + the game is overall too short, its less of an issue since the game is bad, BUT if they had at least solved the issues i mentioned, having a less than 20 hours AAA full priced game is absolutely garbage. I have played a lot of zombie shooters, and looter shooters since those 2 genrers are typically my go-to, and i dont understand how they could screw this game up soo much when it had some of the ideas from those genrers.  Also RX6800XT +I5 12600k/32gb sysram and nvme ssd, cannot keep 60+ stabel on all places in the world at 1440p/epic settings with vsync and motion blur off and no upscaling. For unknown reasons the game suffers from stutter and bad fps drops in heavy town areas, open areas i get 98-118+ fps, BUT i get drops to 55-65 ranges in town areas, and it feels horrible on freesync systems that hits below  the freesync range. THIS is UNACCEPTABLE for a game that looks as bad and dated as redfall does.
